The  global  economic  downturn,  triggered  by  the  collapse  of  the  US 
subprime mortgage market, has turned into one of the sharpest global 
economic recessions in modern history. Most developed economies are 
in  deep  recession  in  2009,  and  the  pace  of  economic  growth  in 
developing countries has declined significantly, and has in some cases 
become  negative.  The  latest  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF) 
projections  suggest  that  economic  growth  in  developed  countries  this 
year will contract by 3.8%. The volume of world trade is expected to fall 
by  12.2%  and  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI)  is  estimated  to  fall  by 
about  30%  from  2008  levels.  Viet  Nam  has  been  severely  affected  by 
the  global  economic  downturn  because  of  the  country’s  increasing 
dependence  on  FDI  inflows  and  exports  to  support  its  high  economic 
growth  rate,  since  its  successful  accession  to  the  World  Trade 
Organization  (WTO)  in  January  2007.  FDI  disbursement  declined  by 
about 18.4% and exports dropped by 10.2% in the first half of 2009. FDI 
approval  fell  by  75%  during  the  same  period.  Remittance  inflows  and 
tourist arrivals also dropped significantly. The global financial crisis has 
affected  the  Government’s  market  access  for  budget  financing.  As  a 
result,  the  Government  has  issued  only  a  limited  amount  of  domestic 
bonds  since  early  2009,  as  bond  yields  in  the  market  remain 
significantly higher than the ceilings set by the Government.  
 
The  Government  is  concerned  about  the  potential  adverse  poverty 
impacts  of  significantly  slower  economic  growth.  Because  of  the 
country’s  young  demographic  profile,  about  1.7  million  young  workers 
enter the country’s labor force annually. During 2006–2007, with annual 
average  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  of  7.6%,  only  about 
800,000 jobs were created annually. With growth projected to decline to 
5%  or  less,  unemployment  and  underemployment  could  increase 
significantly.  At  the  same  time,  the  social  security  system  is  still  in  a 
very  early  stage  of  its  development.  The  Government’s  cash  transfer 
program  has  limited  coverage,  and  is  fraught  with  implementation

The  Government  has  announced  a  significant  fiscal  stimulus  package 
to  counter  the  potential  adverse  impacts  of  the  global  economic 
downturn. The fiscal stimulus package is intended to bolster the primary 
strengths of the economy, maintain GDP growth above 5%, and ensure 
social  stability.  It  broadly  consists  of  four  pillars:  (i) enhancing  state 
investment  funded  from  the  budget  and  additional  bond  issues; 
(ii) exemptions,  reductions,  and  deferments  in  taxes,  intended  to 
support  business  and  bolster  domestic  consumption;  (iii) interest 
subsidies  and  credit  guarantees  intended  to  keep  credit  flowing;  and 
(iv) additional budget expenditure for social welfare. 
 
It is in the context of the second-round effects on the real economy and 
the emerging fiscal constraint that the Government has requested ADB 
to  provide  a  CSF  of  $500 million  to  support  its  public  expenditure 
program  for  2009.  The  request  for  financing  stemmed  from  the 
Government’s  concerns  about  ensuring  predictability  in  its  budget 
financing  since  (i)  market  financing  access  on  reasonable  terms  is 
expected to be limited, and (ii) a larger fiscal stimulus is now needed.  

The  objective  of  the  VIE-CS  loan  is  to  provide  support  for  the 
Government’s countercyclical spending program for 2009 and therefore 
ensure predictability in its budget financing given limited market access 
and  the  need  for  a  temporary  fiscal  expansion.  This  will  allow  the 
Government to promote economic recovery, protect its social spending 
and  poverty  alleviation  programs  and  objectives,  and  continue  with  its 
longer term development objectives in 2009.   

The Government has requested a loan of $500,000,000 under the CSF 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based 
lending  facility  plus  200  basis  points;  a  5-year  term,  including  a  grace 
period  of  3  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan 
Agreement. 
 
The period specified for the VIE-CS will be from 1 September 2009 to 
31 December  2010,  with  a  single  tranche  loan  of  $500  million  to  be 
disbursed  when  the  Government  has  met  the  conditions  for  loan 
effectiveness.

REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE FROM                                                                

THE COUNTERCYCLICAL SUPPORT FACILITY 

2. 
The  proposed  loan  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  (CSF)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) comes at a critical time for Viet Nam. It is designed to maintain the 
momentum  of  the  country’s  key  development  efforts  at  a  challenging  time  of  global  financial 
market  failure  and  the  first  global  recession  since  World  War II.  The  global  crisis,  which 
intensified  after  September  2008,  has  affected  the  Viet  Nam  economy  and  social  sectors  in 
several respects: (i) the surge in commodity prices early in 2008 and the subsequent first-round 
effects  of  the  global  financial  crisis  impacted  on  its  domestic  financial  sector  and  increased 
downside  risks  to  its  external  balance  in  2008;  (ii) the  second-round  effects  of  reduced  global 
demand  have  hurt  the  real  economy  by  stalling  its  two  engines  of  growth—external  trade  and 
foreign  direct  investment  (FDI)—with  economic  growth  in  2009  slowing  to  rates  last  seen  in 
1999;  (iii) the  impact  on  fiscal  policy  has  resulted  in  a  decline  in  tax  revenue  and  a  larger 
government  budget  deficit  than  initially  projected,  at  a  time  of  limited  access  to  international 
credit markets; and (iv) the economic and fiscal policy impacts threaten to undo recent gains in 
poverty reduction. 

3. 
Given the second-round effects on the real economy and the emerging fiscal constraint, 
the Government of Viet Nam asked ADB to provide a countercyclical support loan (VIE-CS) of 
$500  million  to  support  its  2009  and  2010  public  expenditure  programs.  The  Government  is 
concerned about maintaining economic growth above 5% and protecting jobs and stability. It is 
also  concerned  about  ensuring  predictability  in  its  budget  financing,  given  the  necessity  for 
temporary  fiscal  stimulus.  The  Government  projects  gross  financing  requirements  for  2009  at 
D203.5 trillion, including domestic and external debt that matures in 2009. Therefore, the loan 
will provide additional financing to the Government for the larger fiscal stimulus now needed.  

4. 
Adverse  effects  of  the  global  financial  crisis.  The  economy  has  been  adversely 
impacted  by  the  global  economic  crisis.  This  impact  is  manifested  in  several  ways.  Economic 
growth is projected at 3%–5% in 2009, down from an average of 7.6% for the last 4 years. The 
slump  in  FDI,  exports,  and  remittances  are  the  key  factors  behind  this  sharper  than  expected 
economic slowdown. Viet Nam is also experiencing temporary fiscal constraint because of the 
slowdown.  The  2009  budget  plan  projects  government  revenue  to  decline  by  about  3.0%  of 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  below  2008  levels,  primarily  because  of  the  slump  in  resource 
tax revenues. Actual revenue collection in the first half of 2009 was about 5.1% below the target 
specified  in  the  2009  budget  plan.  The  2009  overall  government  budget  deficit  could  rise  to 
10.3% of GDP, including the stimulus spending package, up from 4.1% of GDP in 2008, which 
is  relatively  high  by  international  standards.  However,  ADB  staff  estimate  that  the  cyclically 
adjusted (or underlying) budget deficit is about 4.5% of GDP.

Improved macroeconomic management. The Government has made strong efforts to 
5. 
maintain macroeconomic management of the increased downside risks to the economy arising 
from (i) its own economic overheating in 2007 and the surge in global commodity prices in early 
2008, and (ii) the global financial crisis that intensified in September 2008. The maintenance of 
macroeconomic stability is reflected in inflation declining from its peak of 28% in August 2008 to 
2.0%  in  August  2009  on  a  year-on-year  basis.  Overall,  the  banking  sector  is  sufficiently 
capitalized. While banks’ nonperforming loans (NPLs)2 have risen slightly, they remained low at 
2.2% for the whole banking system in June 2009. The Government has operated overall budget 
deficits  (combined  on-  and  off-budget  balances)  averaging  4%  of  GDP  in  the  last  4  years, 
primarily driven by large capital spending accounting for about 30% of on-budget spending. Viet 
Nam remains at low risk of external debt distress despite the recent deterioration in its economic 
conditions  and  the  global  downturn,  reflecting  Viet  Nam’s  mostly  concessional  and  long-term 
structure  of  external  debt.  The  outlook  for  public  debt  is  less  favorable.  While  it  has  been 
relatively  stable,  at  44.4%  of  GDP,  it  is  moderately  high  for  a  developing  economy  and 
underscores the need for medium-term fiscal consolidation (Appendix 5). However, its external 
position remains vulnerable to modest shocks. Gross international reserves declined from $23.0 
billion at the end of December 2008 to $17.6 billion at the end of June 2009, equivalent to about 
3.7 months  of  import  cover.  Conventionally,  at  least  3.0  months  of  import  coverage  is 
considered a sufficient buffer against modest shocks to the balance of payments. At the same 
time, Viet Nam has a relatively high level of reserves in relation to short term debt. 
 
6. 
Large  fiscal  response.  The Government has announced a countercyclical program to 
mitigate  the  potential  severe  impacts  of  the  global  slowdown  on  Viet  Nam.  The  program 
includes  both  on-  and  off-budget  measures  and  focuses  on  increased  infrastructure  spending, 
temporary tax exemptions, and deferred tax payments intended to support business and bolster 
domestic  consumption;  interest  rate  subsidies  and  credit  guarantees  intended  to  keep  credit 
flowing;  and  additional  budget  expenditure  for  social  welfare.  The  entire  stimulus  package  is 
estimated to amount to D145.6 trillion. The Government intends to use the loan proceeds from 
the  VIE-CS  loan  to  support  its  countercyclical  spending  program  for  2009  and  2010,  and  in 
particular  its  longer  term  infrastructure  development  in  irrigation,  transportation,  and  other 
areas.3

III. 

THE GLOBAL CRISIS AND COUNTRY CONTEXT 

A. 

The Global Crisis and its Impact on Viet Nam’s Economy 

The  global  financial  turmoil  has  affected  developed  and  most  developing  economies, 
10. 
including  Viet  Nam.  The  impact  on  developing  countries  has  varied,  but  generally  the  crisis 
adversely impacted access to global financial markets; and resulted in a sharp downturn in the 
real  economy  with  ensuing  fiscal  stress,  and  higher  unemployment  and  poverty.  The 
International  Monetary  Fund  projects  that  the  global  economy  will  contract  this  year  by  about 
3.8%  and  only  moderately  recover  next  year,  as  financial  market  stabilization  will  take  longer 
than previously envisaged. The volume of world trade is expected to fall by 12.2% and FDI is 
estimated  to  fall  by  about  30%  from  2008  levels.  Developing  country  access  to  international 
credit will remain curtailed as a consequence. 
 
11. 
Four  key  features  of  Viet  Nam’s  recent  economic  developments  are  important  in 
understanding  the  potential  effects  of  the  global  economic  downturn  and  the  Government’s 
determined  policy  response  to  cope  with  the  impacts.  First,  the  country  is  increasingly 
dependent  on  FDI  inflows  and  exports  to  support  its  high  economic  growth  rate,  particularly 
since its successful accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2007. Before 
WTO  accession,  investment  in  Viet  Nam  was  dominated  by  state  investment.  In  2007,  FDI 
disbursement surged by over 90%  and continued to expand strongly in 2008 to reach D192.4 
trillion. As a result, the share of FDI in the country’s total investment increased to 31.5% in 2008, 
from  16.2%  in  2006.  At  the  same  time,  Viet  Nam  traditionally  has  a  very  high  degree  of 
openness to trade, with a trade–GDP ratio of 159% in 2008. Given its high trade intensity, it is 
therefore  highly  vulnerable  to  shocks  to  global  demand.  Second,  Viet  Nam  entered  the  global 
economic  downturn  from  a  position  of  domestic  economic  overheating  in  late  2007  and  early 
2008,  necessitating  a  sharp  reorientation  in  economic  policy  measures.  Third,  unlike  more 
developed  economies  in  the  region,  Viet  Nam  does  not  have  all  the  same  policy  levers  and 
appropriate institutions to address the series of shocks to the economy effectively, and at times 
had to adopt blunt and unconventional measures such as credit subsidies to mitigate the worst 
effects of the crisis on the macroeconomy and labor market. The Government is well aware of 
the  need  for  more  market-based  instruments,  and  is  addressing  these  policy  and  institutional 
constraints  through  ongoing  reforms  including  those  supported  by  the  SIPRP  and  the  World 
Bank’s PRSC series. Finally, Viet Nam has a young demographic profile, and its social security 

 

 system  is  still  in  a  very  early  stage  of  development.  Therefore,  the  global  financial  crisis  has 
major adverse short-term implications for Viet Nam’s labor market and poverty reduction efforts. 
 
12. 
The global commodity price surge. Viet Nam has experienced three major shocks to 
its  economy  in  the  past  18  months.  The  first  was  the  surge  in  global  commodity  prices  that 
spilled over into very high domestic inflation, peaking at 28% in August 2008 on a year-on-year 
basis. This occurred at a time when Viet Nam’s economy exhibited significant signs of economic 
overheating  caused  by  rapid  credit  and  monetary  growth,  fueled  by  large  inflows  of  foreign 
investments.  Consequently,  the  domestic  financial  and  asset  markets  underwent  significant 
correction in the first half of 2008. The equity market was impacted, with equity prices collapsing 
by more than two-thirds in 2008. Property prices also fell in the major urban centers. There was 
some capital flight (of which some was disguised through imports of gold) that put pressure on 
the dong exchange rate to depreciate in the first semester of 2008. 
 
13. 
First-round effects of the global financial crisis. The global financial crisis intensified 
in  September  2008.  However,  the  spillovers  from  the  global  financial  crisis  on  the  Viet  Nam 
domestic  financial  sector—especially  banking—have  been  less  significant  than  in  other 
countries in the region because of limited exposure to troubled US assets, virtually no exposure 
to  securitization  and  off-balance-sheet  activities,  and  of  course  domestic  financial  and  asset 
markets  had  already  experienced  significant  correction.  The  financial  health  of  the  domestic 
banking  system  has  improved  in  recent  years.  Overall,  the  banking  system  is  adequately 
capitalized  but  it  remains  vulnerable  to  the  economic  slowdown,  given  the  rapid  credit  growth 
seen in the last 2 years. The Government’s international reserves position declined from $23.0 
billion  at  the  end  of  2008  to  $17.6  billion  at  the  end  of  June  2009—highlighting  continued 
pressure on its external position.  
 
14. 
The  global  credit  crunch  that  emerged  in  September  2008  hurt  Viet  Nam  as  investors 
became risk averse and reduced demand for Viet Nam debt. Yields on the Government’s global 
bond surged significantly, in line with many countries in the region (Figure 1.c). While the yields 
have gradually declined, they remain elevated. As a result, so far this year the Government has 
only  issued a  small  amount  of  dong-denominated  bonds  and  dollar-denominated  bonds  in  the 
domestic market. The Government has not issued any sovereign bond overseas since 2005. 
 
15. 
Second-round  effects  of  the  global  demand  destruction. The second-round effects 
of the global recession on the Viet Nam economy are greater than the impacts of the 1997/1998 
Asian  financial  crisis.  Total  exports  fell  10.2%  in  the  first  semester  of  2009.  Traditional  labor-
intensive sectors experienced larger contractions, with exports of light industrial and handicrafts 
falling by 25%. The tourism sector also suffered significantly, with tourist arrivals falling 20% in 
the first half of 2009. Disbursements of FDI declined by 18.4% in the first semester of 2009. As 
a  result,  the  Viet  Nam  economy  slowed  to  3.9%  in  the  first  6  months  of  2009  over  the  same 
period  in  2008,  its  lowest  economic  growth  rate  since  1999,  and  well  below  its  average 
economic growth rate of 7.6% in the last 4 years. Of significant concern for poverty reduction, 
the inflows of remittances have dropped sharply by 26% in the first half of 2009, down to $2.7 
billion from $3.7 billion for the same period in 2008. 
 
16.  With this background, it is expected that economic growth for 2009 will be about 3.0%–
5.0%  because  of  faltering  exports,  slowing  foreign  investments,  and  the  drop  in  remittances. 
These  projections  translate  to  lower  per  capita  income  growth  of  1.5%–3.5%  in  2009,  thereby 
likely increasing poverty (para. 17).

poverty  alleviation  programs  and  objectives,  and  continue  with  its  longer  term  development

The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $500,000,000  under  the  CSF  from  ADB’s

ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility on

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues  
 
Viet Nam has been severely affected by the global economic downturn because of the country’s increasing dependence on 
foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows and exports to support its high economic growth rate since its successful accession to 
the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  in  January  2007.  FDI  disbursement  dropped  by  18.4  and  exports  declined  by  about 
10.2% in the first half of 2009. Remittance inflows and tourist arrivals also dropped significantly. The global financial crisis also 
affected  the  Government’s  market  access  for  budget  financing.  As  a  result,  the  Government  has  not  issued  any  bond 
domestically  since  early  2009  as  bond  yields  in  the  market  remain  significantly  higher  than  the  ceilings  set  by  the 
Government.  The  Government  is  concerned  about  the  potential  adverse  poverty  impacts  of  significantly  slower  economic 
growth. Because of the country’s young demographic profile, about 1.7 million young workers enter the labor force annually. 
During  2006–2007,  with  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  averaging  7.6%,  only  about  800,000  jobs  were  created 
annually.  Since  growth  is  projected  to  decline  to  5%  or  less,  unemployment  and  underemployment  could  increase 
significantly. At the same time, the social security system is still in a very early stage of its development. The Government’s 
cash transfer program has limited coverage, and is fraught with implementation problems. Therefore, preventing a collapse of 
economic activities and sustaining employment are the most effective social security response. 
 
2.  Design Features  
 
The VIE-CS provides budget support for the Government’s countercyclical public spending program in infrastructure and the 
social sectors. It is aimed to ensure predictability in budget financing for 2009, as a larger national government budget deficit 
is required than initially planned.

consideration  by  the  Board.  It  includes  triggers  for  subsequent  subprograms  to  ensure  a 
continuous dialogue between the Government, development partners, and stakeholders. Broad-
based,  well-targeted  policy  actions  designed  to  achieve  a  continued  reduction  in  poverty 
enhance Viet Nam’s economic competitiveness and strengthen the foundations for inclusive and 
sustainable growth and a continued reduction in poverty beyond 2010. In this way, the SIPRP V 
provides  a  coherent  medium-term  reform  strategy  with  three  discrete  but  linked  subprograms

1. 
This  appendix  summarizes  the  determinants  of  the  size  and  composition  of  fiscal 
stimulus packages and draws on the findings a number of recent International Monetary Fund 
(IMF)  cross-country  studies. 1 Two  sets  of  factors  help  explain  the  relative  size  of  stimulus 
packages: (i) differences across countries in the need for stimulus, and (ii) differences in fiscal 
space. 
 
Need  for  stimulus.  The  magnitude  of  the  overall  fiscal  expansion  (including  both 
2. 
discretionary  and  nondiscretionary  components)  should  depend  on  the  size  of  the  output  gap 
that  each  country  faces  in  the  absence  of  fiscal  support.  The  fiscal  expansion  in  a  particular 
country should also be larger if multipliers are lower.   
 
3. 
Composition  of  stimulus.  Fiscal  stimulus  packages  are  typically  comprised  of  (i)  tax-
related measures, (ii) social sector spending, and (iii) infrastructure expenditures. However, the 
weight  given  to  any  one  of  these  components  depends  on  preexisting  fiscal  characteristics. 
Countries  in  which  the  automatic  stabilizers  are  smaller  (e.g.,  those  that  have  less  extensive 
social benefits programs) will require greater discretionary stimulus—this is true of most of the 
countries  in  Asia  in  relation  to  developed  economies.  Tax  stimulus  measures  can  be 
implemented  relatively  quickly  and  their  impact  is  already  being  felt  in  the  fiscal  accounts. 
Expenditure  measures,  however,  tend  to  proceed  more  slowly,  reflecting  normal  budgetary 
controls and typical start-up delays in new programs. Multipliers, however, tend to be higher for 
expenditure-related  stimulus  measures  than  for  tax-related  ones.  Figure  A10  provides  a 
breakdown  of  the  composition  of  stimulus  packages  in  selected  Southeast  Asian  countries. 
Finally,  coordination  of  stimulus  packages  across  countries  is  crucial  to  maximizing  their 
effectivity in the context of a global crisis. 
 
4. 
Differences  in  fiscal  space.  Key  factors  that  determine  a  country’s  fiscal  space  to 
expand include levels of deficits, public debt, contingent liabilities, and interest rates.  Countries 
facing  relatively  higher  real  interest  rates  or  elevated  debt  levels  have  less  room  to  expand; 
competing crisis-related needs, such as for financial sector support (mainly in the United States 
and Europe), are also factors in determining available fiscal space. 
 
5.

appropriate policy  design.  Ideally,  a  larger  fiscal  expansion in  times  of economic  crisis  can  be 
accommodated  if  policy  design  increases  the  likelihood  of  a  fiscal  tightening  once  conditions 
improve, to ensure long-term fiscal solvency. In this respect, the IMF has offered a number of
